name: general
text: <@U02918BKW|john> has renamed the channel from "general-old" to "general"
sigh, general is a protected name.
whats the problem?
slack keeps all the files, and doesn't auto-delete them.

so we've hit a point where the file history has gone over some threshold and we're supposed to upgrade, or delete. file deletion is one at a time, or you can delete an archived channel and wipe out a lot. i probably bought us a week or whatever by deleting shutup.
hooooly crap you can really only delete one at a time?
those bastards
or a channel at a time. but general, which proooobably is the majority of files, cannot be archived
"Note that deleting a channel will not delete the files that were shared into the deleted channel, nor will it change the visibility of those files"
it seems to have
we had 26 pages of files, now we have less.
<https://blog.svpino.com/2014/11/13/how-to-bulk-remove-files-from-slack>

attachments.title: How to bulk remove files from Slack
attachments.text: We are starting to roll out Slack at my company. Coming from Skype, Slack feels just right for us, so I'm very excited about the transition. However, the basic plan comes with just 5GB of file storage and we already found ourselves out of space.
attachments.fallback: svpino.com: How to bulk remove files from Slack

text: looks promising
oo
do it!
he removed all files older than 30 days
when you're not busy. the annoying message is gone now.
is there a date cutoff we'd be happy with?
that works for me. active channels usually only go back a couple of weeks anyway
Also keep in mind that I think some people upload design files over DM
<@U026E0ZNR> do you ever need to go back more than 30 days?
it might be the price we have to pay
I usually can't
Things get archived before 1 week for me
I've gone referencing important conversations from less than a week ago and they will be gone past the 10,000 message mark
of possible interest, matt and evans lead the pack for file count. i think justin is next up at about half matt's 169 file PR. or maybe gaston.

<@U02613K0X> until we're willing to pay $7/mo/user for slack, i think putting up with files vanishing after 30 days is more than reasonable. communications of an artifact nature shouldn't be on slack anyway due to the 10k message limit.
agreed
okay i'm doing it
in the distant future when you're bored, right? :wink:
oh yes
I regret nothing!
does matt get a prize?
thanks <@U02613K0X>!
I think it might be good to point out that people should maybe use dropbox for files and post dropbox links rather than straight uploading the files.
only problem with that is that it creates another step. slack is nice because you can send files easily and quickly
I rarely post files. It's all linked images. Not gonna stop doing that.
You can but should you? Does it take up as much space in our allotted storage if we post links over actual files?
Smaller jpgs are fine but when you get to movie clips and large zip files that gets to be too weighty
i mean, people can upload files all they want, as long as theyre ok with them disappearing in 30 days
point is, don't use this thing for file storage
Yup
I think I missed something about this 30 days thing...
yeah, it was posted in general a while back by <@U0265G76F> - just noting that anything important or something you may want to reference later, just default to emailing it.
<@U026E0ZNR> slack puts a limit on file storage for basic accounts... and we've just reached that limit. Jenny found a script that auto-deletes any files older than 30 days from slack's servers
slack only lets you delete one at a time 'cause they sneaky and want our money
oh there's a script. didn't read the article. :grin:
So what I'm wondering then is if we still need to worry about the amount of file uploads we do within those 30 days
Like will we max out before then if we aren't careful?
I doubt it
We just now maxed out and we've been on slack for how long?
also - you can link files from Slack to Google Drive, so we don't tap into our Slack limits
Sorry I'm late to the party but there should also be a way to link to NAS files.
That way we keep NAS as the single source of truth for all files.

<@U02618EV1> slack shouldn't be used for artifact based communication because people won't be able to find the message later. send an email with official stuff. ad hoc daily comms and temporary sharing, yay slack!
